title: civil servants derry pledge take strike action
story: Civil service workers in Derry have pledged to take further industrial action after a strike was held on Friday.Following Friday’s pickets, Civil Service workers affiliated to public service Trade Union NIPSA were told that Sue Gray, Permanent Secretary at the Department of Finance, “doesn’t give a damn about you”.They were cautioned that one day of action would not be enough to bring about meaningful change, therefore, plans are in motion to take further strike action.Comments made by NIPSA’s Deputy General Secretary, Carmel Gates, were greeted by applause when she called for additional strike days from today onwards and action short of all-out strikes.Members of political parties were present to show their support, including representatives from Sinn Fein, the SDLP and People Before Profit.Workers in Derry and Belfast gathered for strike action over pay and conditions.NIPSA members in the NI Civil Service were on the picket lines at a number of buildings in Derry. Those included Foyle Jobs and Benefits Office on Asylum Road, Carlisle House on Carlisle Road and Orchard House on Foyle Street from early morning until .am.After the picket lines, members gathered for a rally at the City Hotel which began at .am.The -hour strike was organised to highlight an imposed “pay deal” of .% and changes to terms and conditions of employment which union officials claim have been implemented without proper and meaningful consultation.Ms Gates addressed the rally along with Gerry Murphy, President of Irish Congress of Trade Unionsand Niall McCarroll, Chairman of the Derry Trades Union Council .Mr McCarroll addressed a packed room at the City Hotel where he said all workers had taken action to bring about better working conditions.He said the Tory government was “attacking working class communities” and it is time to “fight back” by building solidarity amongst workers. “Let us together build up a working-class spirit and let the Tories know we can bring them down.”Meanwhile, Ms Gates was keen to dispel the notion of civil servants having well-paid “cushy jobs” as an “absolute myth”. She added: “There are civil servants relying on tax credits, second jobs, credit cards to bring them to the end of the month or to pay off debts and those using food banks.”She praised those in the room for leading the way, recognising that many,not all of them, could ill afford to go without pay for the day. “We have to say, enough is enough, they can’t keep piling work on us and saying they can’t even give us a decent pay increase.“Many workers are % worse off than ten years ago in real terms.”Referring to legal action which has been initiated for “failure to consult”, she informed those in attendance, that the judge has decided to forego a pre-hearing by instead fixing a court date.She added that there will be a “few white faces” in the Department of Finance who know their actions have been “discriminatory” as they have been “acting outside the law”. And concluded by saying “it’s time to strike a blow for all workers”.Other members of the audience were afforded an opportunity to speak and one worker, named Amy, said the government does not care about workers standards of living, nor their mental and physical health. She demanded a living wage for all.A motion was put forward by People Before Profit at last month’s full Council meeting calling on the Permanent Secretary at the Department of Finance to provide a “fair and just settlement” which was backed by all councillors. PBP Councillor Shaun Harkin voiced his support for all “necessary action”.NIPSA representative Ruaidhri O’Sandair had one final message for the department of Finance, “Sue Gray, where’s our pay ”googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refresh

title: derry city cemetery series dr walter bernard man preserved myths magic grianan aileach
story: Today the Irish Government lists the ancient Grianan of Aileach fort, just seven miles from Derry city, as a national monument. It is perched above the Co Donegal village of Burt and attracts thousands of visitors every year.The fort is a powerful manestation of what remains of ancient Ireland and on a clear day, from its pinnacle, it is possible to get a glimpse of three counties-Donegal, Derry and Tyrone. The commanding and spectacular waterways of Lough Swilly and Lough Foyle lie to its west and east respectively.But, in the th Century the fort, once home to kings of old Gaelic order, was rapidly disintegrating towards extinction. It was however saved by the vision of one man who spearheaded its restoration just over  years ago.Dr Walter Bernard was born on May ,  at Newmarket, Co Cork. His father was a captain in the th Rles, a regiment of the British Army and was amongst the reinforcements that arrived in Brussels on the eve of the Battle of Waterloo in June of  but was apparently too late to take part in the famed history changing conflict.Walter became a Member of the Royal College of Surgeons of Great Britain and Ireland in , a Licentiate of the Royal College of Physicians of Ireland in  and Fellow of that college in .Between - Dr Bernard served as a surgeon throughout the Crimean War attending the wounded British soldiers at Inkerman and witnessed the ravages caused by small pox and cholera. He later recalled that for every man that was shot, fty more were killed by those diseases, particularly in the notoriously harsh winters of  and .On the journey home from the Ukranian battlefields, he saved a man from drowning and was awarded with a certicate from the Royal Humane Society. Then, with his experiences of military conflict at an end, Dr Bernard landed back in Ireland and settled in Buncrana before building up a very large medical practice in Derry. He ran this surgery for over sixty years and was a prominent member of the city’s branch of the British Medical Association as well as holding many public offices throughout his career.One such appointment was to examine the quality of water in the city for Londonderry Corporation at public facilities such as the Creggan reservoirs built in stages between -, and which supplied much of the city’s domestic and industrial water needs.His experience of the waterborne disease cholera in the Crimea made him an ideal candidate for this job.Dr Bernard also addressed the Medical Society of King and Queens College of Physicians on the issuer of diphtheria in April . He cautioned the assembled medics that there was a reason why the disease was largely absent from statistics sheets.He said: “There are few diseases about which so many mistakes in diagnosis are made.”He feared the misdiagnosis rate was so high that it was almost impossible to ensure that ‘true diphtheria’ was as common in a town as reported.Dr Bernard added: “Diphtheria occurs in Londonderry, I have no doubt whatever…in my practice it has been my lot to treat many cases of this disease.”At some point in , Dr Bernard paid a visit to Grianan of Aileach and many years later in , he said of the experience: “Seventeen years ago, when this traditional and historical place was first visited by me, I found it in a very ruinous condition, and from that time I commenced to take an interest in its associations.“Year after year I witnessed further advance of its ruin, and I clearly saw thatsomething were not soon done to arrest the progress of its destruction, it would be in a few years a thing of the past.”Grianan of Aileach is a hilltop fort that sits on top of Greenan Mountain in Inishowen just over  feet above ground level.The ringfort was thought to have been built in the sixth or seventh century, although there is some evidence to suggest that the site had been in use before that.Greek astronomer and cartographer Ptolemy penned a remarkably accurate map of Ireland in  A.D. from which maps were later created in the th and th centuries. He called the land ‘Iouernia’, thought to mean ‘abundant land’ from which the Irish names Eriu and Eire are derived. Amongst two sites identied as ‘regia’ or royal places in Ireland by the Greek map maker, one of them is believed by some historians to be the Grianan of Aileach.Whether Ptolemy pinpointed it or not, the Kingdom of Aileach was indeed one of Ireland’s royal sites of the Gaelic order. The fort was thought to have been constructed originally by the northern section of the Ui Neill clan, but between  A.D. and the thirteen centuries, over  kings from ious clans, some also High Kings of Ireland, held the throne of Aileach. The last man to be known as the King of Aileach was Aed Buide Ua Neill who died in .Despite ious interpretations, it is generally agreed that Aileach means ‘stony place’ and the word Grianan means ‘sunny place’ so that Grianan of Aileach broadly translates as ‘The Stone Palace of the Sunny View’.Whatever the actual meaning of its name, it is evident that it was an extremely important place. Aileach’s political and strategic importance was such that the annals of Irish history record that it was attacked at least three times. In , Finsnechta Fledach, King of Ireland, destroyed the fort.Again, in , when Muirchertach MacNeill was king, Viking raiders sacked the site when they settled at Lough Swilly and Lough Foyle. It’s also thought that King Brian Boru came to Aileach in , but it was destroyed once more in , when another King of Munster, Muirchertach Ua Briaincame to Inishowen and plundered the region and razed the fort. The fort was laid to waste by O’Brien in revenge for O’Neill’s destruction of his royal seat at Kincora and he reportedly told his soldiers to each take a stone from the Donegal hillside so the place would be reduced to rubble.The fort itself could have served two main s both as a defensive and a ceremonial one and moreover as a settlement that was surrounded by ringforts of lesser importance. Whatever its actual , it is known that buildings of this nature were very rare in North West Ulster and its presence signies that its inhabitants were regarded as being very important.googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refreshThe linking of St Patrick to the site is seen as attempt by Christian converts to place it firmly in that tradition whilst acknowledging its pagan history and the naming of a holy well right outside the ringfort in honour of Ireland’s patron saint seems to confirm that.There is also a mythological and folklore version of the founding of Grianan of Aileach which says the ringfort was built by Dagda , a god and the king of the Tuatha De Danann-the supposed ‘Tribe of the Gods’-a supernatural race in Irish mythology. The Tuatha De Danann are said to have invaded Ireland before the Celts and built strategic stone forts on the tops of hills.Dagda was said to have fought the Second Battle of Moytirra against the Fomorians and the fort at Aileach was built over the grave of his son Aedh who had been murdered.In , a Derry based group called the Irish Irelanders, enthusiastic Gaelic revivalists travelled to the site on Sunday afternoons and carried out some repairs. But, the splendour and historical intrigue of Grianan of Aileach had largely been ignored for many years until in , Dr Walter Bernard decided to begin its restoration in earnest.In the s, painter, musician, antiquarian and archaeologist George Petrie examined Grianan of Aileach when he was head of the Royal Irish Academy’s antiquities committee which was linked to the Irish Ordnance Survey.Petrie’s findings suggested that the hill many have been enclosed by many other ramparts and a line of stones leading up to the entrance which were all gone by then.But, despite his efforts, the expert’s findings remained confined to the records of the Royal Irish Academy, there were no efforts by the organisation to attempt any restoration of the ancient site.It was Dr Bernard who took practical action beyond the analysis of the site. He paid for the entire project that took place between - and recruited his crew of labourers from the farms surrounding Burt. They ferried the materials needed for the restoration on the back up small carts up supplied by the local landowners up the incredibly steep hill.What the doctor found at the site was a disorganised mess of which he said it was: “An immense circular heap of stones, with its grey fallen masonry scattered over the interior-no vestige of a wall, entrance passage, or central building.”Remembering that Walter Bernard was a medical doctor with no detailed description of what an ancient ringfort truly looked like and that there weren’t enough stones on site to complete the job, makes this story even more remarkable.Dr Bernard discovered many animal bones on the site including sheep, cows and goats and items like sling stones and warrior’s clubs. The most interesting stone object discovered was a ‘slab of sandstone, chequered into thirty-six squares’, believed to be a games board of some type.The doctor and his crew of labourers used the measurements of other Irish forts such as Staigue Fort in Co Kerry as the comparative basis for the restoration project at Grianan of Aileach. The finished product is a fort that stands . metres in diameter and more than five metres tall with walls that are almost four metres thick.Dr Bernard later described a part of the building project by saying: “To bind our work into a complete unity we had to gather around the hill about  or  loose stones-certainly not more,so many-and to split from the adjoining rocks, cropping up through the heather,  coping stones. These are supposed to serve instead of those removed by King Murdock O’Brien in .”Only speculation can be used to assessthe interior of today’s fort accurately resembles its ancient predecessor, but when the alternative was the complete disappearance of the Iron Age construction, then surely Bernard’s efforts become even more admirable.The fort has stood for centuries as a silent witness to major events of Irish history. From the top of Grianan fort you can just make out the location of the Co Donegal village of Rathmullen on the western bank of Lough Swilly.It was from Rathmullen in  that the chieftains Hugh O’Neill and Rory O’Donnell sailed with their families after the final defeat by the English taking with them the last symbols of the old Gaelic order once enshrined in its pomp by places such as Grianan of Aileach. Behind them in the distance the old fort sat on its hilltop as a fading reminder of a society and its traditions that would never .A legend says that in a secret cave on a hill beneath Grianan O’Neill’s warriors rest in a bewitched sleep in full armour and sitting on their horses ready for the next fight. The spell, says the legend, will only be broken when the next destined leader of Ulster arrives to lead them to victory.It is a myth that would have no visible attachmentit had not been for the passion of Dr Walter Bernard in the late th century in restoring Grianan of Aileach to something approaching its former glory.A tourist road to the fort was opened on September ,  by President of Ireland Eamon De Valera who was accompanied by Fine Gael TD for Donegal West, Pat O’Donnell, then Minister for Local Government. In the early s the Office of Public Works in the Republic of Ireland carried out further repairs to Grianan of Aileacgh after a wall collapsed. But as late as October  the Irish Government was being severely criticised by political representatives in Donegal for still failing to establish tour guides and other facilities at the ancient site.In his obituary contained in the Universities and Colleges magazine of December , , it was reported that Dr Bernard died suddenly at his residence in Buncrana on eight days previously on December . He was -years-old and was buried in Derry City Cemetery.Dr Bernard’s obituary ended: “He leaves a widow. His le was deeply scarred by three great sorrows, the deaths of his three children.”CAPTION: The volunteers involved in the restoration of Grianan of Aileach pictured at its official re-opening in .

title: derry university group ready support development north west institution
story: The Derry University Group has said it is willing to “advise and support” the local council in establishing an independent university in the city.A meeting was held between Council Chief Executive John Kelpie, Deputy Mayor Cara Hunter, and the new Secretary of State for NI this week where the ongoing campaign for a Medical school at Magee was discussed.The Derry University Groupfelt it was a prime opportunity to impress upon SoS Julian Smith the need for an independent university in the city.This month, Derry City  Strabane District Councillors unanimously backed a motion supporting the exploration of all options for university provision in the North West. That included the expansion of Magee and the possibility of an independent university put forward by the DUG.The move followed an intervention by Labour Peer Lord Adonis who convinced the House of Lords to publish a report on the improvement of higher education provision in Northern Ireland and the establishment of a university whose principal campus is in Derry.A spokesperson for the Derry University Group said it is clear that the momentum for a dedicated university for the North West is growing all the time.“In recent months, Derry Strabane Council and other major influencers in Westminster and Dublin have committed themselves to delivering an independent university for the North West.“There has also been huge support from US colleges, who want to partner with a standalone university in Derry. It is completely apparent that the public here want action from the governments on a new university, now, as a matter of urgent priority.”“The North West, despite the political uncertainty, is in a prime position to establish a new cultural and educational institution, which could act as a catalyst for the economic regeneration of the region and reverse the damage already being done by Brexit on the Derry and Donegal communities.“The Derry University Group is willing to advise and assist Council and others in developing and delivering a new university, as we have always done in the past. title: national hunger strike commemoration take place strabane sunday
story: This Sunday, August , for the first time the National Hunger Strike Commemoration will be held for the first time in Strabane.Thirty-eight years after ten republicans died in Long Kesh during the spring and summer of , thousands of people from across Ireland will march from Lford across the border to the west Tyrone town to remember the prison battle conducted against the Thatcher administration’s policy of criminalisation.Speaking at the announcement that Strabane will host the event, Sinn Fein’s West Tyrone MP Orfhlaith Begley said it was a privilege for Strabane republicans and the rest of the constituency to host the event.“The  hunger strike was a watershed in Irish history and had a profound impact in terms of radicalising communities throughout Ireland. This impact was particularly felt in areas like here in Strabane where pride in the hunger strikers, their courage and sacrice still remains undiminished almost  years on.”The roots of what took place in  began several years earlier, when in  Belfast republican Kieran Nugent became the first man to refuse to wear a prison unorm. In , republicans had been accorded what the British termed Special Category Status recognising the political nature of their offences.By the mid-s however, political status had been withdrawn and as the cages of Long Kesh were replaced by the concrete H Blocks, the new British policy of ‘normalisation’ was wholly designed to strike any notion of political credence away from the IRA campaign.When he entered the H Blocks, Kieran Nugent was instructed to put a prison unorm on by the authorities. He answered, ‘you’ll have to nail it to my back.’ This began five years of protest inside the prison and heightened violence outside it which resulted in dozens of deaths.The blanket and no wash protests of the first four years of the prison conflict yielded no concessions on the issue of political status.The years of isolation and living in dire conditions eventually brought the situation to a head. The choice was plain and stark. The protesting republican prisoners could either concede and serve out jail sentences classed as ‘ordinary criminals’ or escalate the protest to the last ‘weapon’ available to them inside a prison-the hunger strike.It was not a new tactic for the republican movement, and it drew its inspiration from stories from the old Gaelic order.It’s recorded in the annals of Irish history that when a citizen felt slighted by the ruling order, it was not uncommon for them to lie outside their dwelling and refuse food in the hope of publicly shaming the guilty party into reparation and or an apology.In , Thomas Ashe died in Mountjoy prison in Dublin after being force fed whilst on hunger strike demanding political status. Then, in , the Lord Mayor of Cork Terence McSwiney died after  days whilst on hunger strike in Brixton jail. And, next year in  to mark the centenary of the death of McSwiney, the National Hunger Strike Commemoration will take place in Cork city.Back in , Michael Gaughan died in Parkhurst on the Isle of Wight after  days on hunger strike, and shortly before the beginning of the prison blanket and no wash protests in Long Kesh, in February , another Mayo man, Frank Stagg died at Wakefield jail in Yorkshire after  days without food.The first Long Kesh hunger strike began on October , . The protestors set out a list of five demands: -The right not to wear a prison unorm -The right not to do prison work -The right of free association with other prisoners -The right to organise their own educational and recreational facilities and -The right to one visit, one letter and one parcel a week.Seven men, including Sinn Fein MLA Raymond McCartney said they would fast to the death in the pursuit of the re-establishment of political status. Simultaneously, three female republican prisoners also embarked on a strike in Armagh jail.As Christmas  approached, the British offered a deal which appeared to agree to the central demand of the right not to wear a prison unorm. One of the hunger strikers, Sean McKenna was close to death at this stage and the strike was called off. It later emerged that was really being offered was a deal to allow prisoners to wear ‘civilian type clothing’ supplied by the prison regime. The scene was therefore already set for a second strike.It began on March ,  when Bobby Sands refused to eat. Raymond McCartney said: “Obviously everybody’s memory of  is the fact that ten people died on hunger strike.“On March ,  the British Government removed political status. I think most people thought that this was a half-hearted attempt and they’d roll over within a short period of time.“But, clearly what was emerging was a complete change in policy by the British Government who were intent on the idea of ‘normalisation’, ‘criminalisation’ and ‘Ulsterisation’.“Instinctively, any of us who found ourselves in prison at that time, knew we were political prisoners and any attempt to criminalise us just wasn’t going to work. It became a battle of wills.“But, I think by the end of the hunger strike in October, , most people looking on were saying that whatever was going on in the North that nobody in their wildest notion thought it was a criminal conspiracy. They certainly saw it as a political conflict. They may not have agreed with the armed actions of the IRA, but they certainly viewed it as a political situation.“So, for us by that stage, the process of criminalisation was in tatters. But, there was a very high price paid because  people had died in prison and  or  people had died on the streets.“Within the prisons we knew that we still had work to do because what we had to do was turn that acceptance of political imprisonment into every day conditions. By the end of the hunger strike I suppose there was a big recognition of the dference between the criminal’s unorm and our own clothes was one manestation of it. And, over the years we continued to ensure the conditions in Long Kesh reflected that.“By the late s and early s, journalists were frequent visitors to the prison and left with the overwhelming impression that we were a ‘dferent type’ of prisoner. They may have gone out and had questions about who you were and what you were about but they were in doubt that we were political prisoners. That was a big source of validation.”The intensity of the events and scale of death and destruction between  and  in retrospect now seems enormous, but Raymond McCartney maintains that it paved the way for future political developments.“It was only five years, but it was a very intense five years. It is only when you get a bit older you realise just how short a time span it was, because when you roll onto  and the Good Friday Agreement there was an acceptance of the framework that there was a political conflict which had to be resolved by political means-the recognition of political mandates, the political framework to address all these issues, but at the core of that was the acceptance of political prisoners.googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refresh“There is no doubt there is evidence that there were elements within the British Government were determined that political status should not be granted for whatever reason.“Even in , when there was internment without trial and up to , people were held in conditions where they wore their own clothes. There was a recognition of the political conflict of one nature or another.“How that was defined by dferent people is a dferent matter. I know that other people have made the observation that for too long the British tried to deal with the North as a security issue. therefore, when you have a security mentality or emergency laws, emergency courts, emergency interrogation centres, everything is changed and turned upside down.“If you follow their logic from that point of view and they say ‘you cannot now say you are political prisoners’ whilst trying to pretend that everything  about the situation isn’t political too then the penny drops in a whole lot of ways.”The almost  years since  have provoked much debate within wider nationalism about whether or not the hunger strike was harnessed as a catalyst for the republican movement to embark on the path to politics.The election of Bobby Sands to Westminster and Kieran Doherty to the Dail was followed quickly by a debate within Sinn Fein about ending their policy of abstentionism from political institutions that would lead to a split in the republican movement in . The Derry News asked Raymond McCartney for his view on this.He said: “It is interesting now, because everyone has their story about what the origins of the peace process was. But, there is absolutely no doubt that when you look back as far as  that Gerry Adams that there needed to be a political way of resolving the conflict, because military stalemate was exactly that.“The famous Glover Report from the British Army accepted that there was not going to be a military defeat, was them in their own way, saying the IRA was a political force and that the guys in Long Kesh were political prisoners. They job they were sent to do, they couldn’t do and that was to impose a military defeat and by extension their laws of oppression were not going to work either.“It made the situation painful and made the conflict last longer. Then, whenever the formula for the Good Friday Agreement was put forward, some former prisoners will tell you that it was too high a price to pay, but the core accepted it was a political problem and without political solutions it was never going to be resolved.”When the first hunger strike ended in October of , Raymond McCartney had gone without food for  days. So, what are his own personal recollections of the physical effects of what took place “I suppose when you look at that time in , Martin Hurson died after  days whilst others like Kevin Lynch were approaching  days when he died.“In a very strange way hunger strike affects dferent people in dferent ways. Even the day the hunger strike ended in , I was still walking about, I was out of bed. But, there is no doubt that your body slows down.“My ability to see was greatly affected. But, the body is a remarkable piece of equipment and resilience is obviously built in. As you get older you reflect on it and it is dficult to work out in your head that you could sustain doing without food for  days and others for  days.“I suppose when you look at that time in , Martin Hurson died after  days whilst others like Kevin Lynch were approaching  days when he died. In a very strange way hunger strike affects dferent people in dferent ways.“Even the day the hunger strike ended in , I was still walking about, I was out of bed. But, there is no doubt that your body slows down. My ability to see was greatly affected.“As you get older you reflect on it and it is dficult to work out in your head that you could sustain doing without food for  days and others for  days.”Undoubtedly, it was Margaret Thatcher more than anyone  within the British establishment at the time who demonstrated complete determination to use the protests in Long Kesh to ide and break the republican movement.Many commentators have pointed to the INLA assassination of her colleague Airey Neave in  as one reason why the British Prime Minister embarked on a path of total intransigence towards the IRA. However, Raymond McCartney believes that her thinking was a lot wider than that.“Whatever her antipathy towards Ireland was and what came with that, she was setting out a broader political stall. Look at how she treated the miner’s later on.“Reading state papers now, years after these events, her take on the miner’s strike wasn’t just a battle about conditions in the mines, it was about strategically tackling trade unions. It was a case of her saying who is the strongest union-who is the spine of the working class and acting on that.“I always remember that being in jail gives you the time to reflect and read and think and I also always remember that Bobby Sands out of all the people who had been in jail was very clear about what he was there for because he wrote it all down. Some of the things he wrote captures the way a writer works-it’s all encompassing and puts it out there in a very vivid way.“I had previously been interned, I had an understanding about what being a political prisoner was. You had your own clothes and a bit of freedom to associate with other prisoners and you didn’t feel that sense of captivity although you were locked up. Bobby Sands caught on very early that the British were trying to defeat us in the prisons. It wasn’t just about trying to give you a hard time or denying you your own clothes, it was that they had a core idea to break us.“One of the rewarding things for me personally was that the system we had in the end in jail was one based on equality. That we treated people as equals. If you couldn’t treat the person beside you as a comrade and an equal that you couldn’t expect anyone  to believe that you’d treat all people as equals as you went on through le.”Those wishing to attend the th National Hunger Strike Commemoration are asked to assemble on Sunday, August  at .pm at the Diamond in Lford before marching across the border into Strabane where Martina Anderson MEP will deliver this year’s main oration.CAPTION: Raymond McCartney spent  days on hunger strike in .

title: waterfoot park residents take council task proposed construction development
story: Derry City and Strabane District Councilhas pledged to engage fully with a group of residents in the Waterside after they accused the local authority of failing to fulfil their obligations in relation to their objections to a potential building development in their district.In July last year, residents of Waterfoot Park in the city lodged a formal objection to plans for a housing development in the area seeking to construct four semi-detached houses, two detached houses and six, two-bedroomed apartments.The Waterfoot Park residents objected to the proposed development on several grounds which included the potential impact of the construction project on existing properties at the site and that the planning application had not indicated accurate separation and height dferences between the proposed new project and the existing homes.A statement from the Waterfoot Park Residents Objectors Committee to the Derry News said: “The proposed dwellings are three stories in height on ground over two metres higher than the existing houses with restricted separation distances between both.“The layout would result in loss of privacy, natural light, sunlight and overbearing dominance, creating a sense of being hemmed in for us existing residents living adjacent to the boundary line.“Our concerns are also for the natural habitat of wildle species and the overall vast vegetation and trees. No details were provided on how existing vegetation will be retained and no bioersity checklist was provided.”The residents also employed planning consultant Lee Kennedy, who told the Council of his concerns that some demolition work to existing buildings on the proposed development site had already taken place, prior to planning approval and that trees had been felled along the rear boundary of the site close to the homes of the objectors.A spokesperson for the Waterfoot residents said: “Mr Kennedy went onto state that residents have expressed genuine fears about a threat to the remaining vegetation on the application site.“He reminded Council that they hold a duty of care to work in the public interest and offer protection to the remaining mature trees, by the serving of a Provisional Tree Preservation Orderunder the  Planning Act.”Mr Kennedy confirmed to the Derry News that he had submitted a request for a TPO from the Council, but “no action had been taken.”However, the Waterfoot Park residents say their fears were heightened again earlier this month when a team of workers appeared on the proposed development site and began to cut down more trees.A spokesperson for the residents told the Derry News: “On Friday, July  at .am the neighbours were woken with the sound of several power saws and saw a full team of tree cutters on site behind them.googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refresh“Within an hour they had created absolute mayhem on the site, with trees felled all around and they were left when they fell. The ground and houses nearby vibrated and caused house alarms to go off.“Some neighbours felt very intimidated, shocked and panicked with the suddenness, noise level and by the time of the morning it happened. The residents are up in arms. It should never have been allowed to happen as Council was made aware last year about their responsibility of a duty of care to work in the public interest. The residents feel unsupported to date in their endeavours to the Council.”Addressing the residents’ concerns, a spokesperson for Derry City and Strabane District Council said that: “During the processing of the application,  objections have been received to the proposed development.“Correspondence to the Planning Department from Planning Consultant, Mr Lee Kennedy acting on behalf of the objectors, was received on August ,  and raised concerns regarding the trees on the site, and a request for a Provisional Tree Preservation Orderto be served on the site.“These concerns were raised with the Planning Department’s Tree Preservation Officer on September ,  who advised on September , that in his professional opinion, a TPO was not appropriate for this site given the nature, type and scale of trees.”On April  this year, Planning Department officials met with objectors at the city’s Council offices, where again, the Tree Preservation Officer advised that a TPO was considered but was unnecessary when assessed against the criteria required for a TPO.The Council spokesperson continued: “The site was further inspected by planning officers on June ,  and officers met with objectors on site.“More recently, the case officer wrote to the agent and the applicant on June ,  to advise that further information was required. Amongst other things requested, the case officer advised that a tree survey of the site was required, a landscaping plan to show existing trees and vegetation to be retained and additional planting to be shown and a bioersity checklist was to be submitted to advise on any existing ecology on the site.“The agent confirmed in correspondence dated, July  that a Phase  habitat survey was instructed to be carried out as well as a tree survey and would be submitted in due course.”However, the Council spokesperson added: “The Planning Department were made aware by an objector by email on July ,  that eight trees along the boundary of the site adjacent to properties in Waterfoot Park had been felled on July  at .am.“Council takes its obligations in respect of these matters seriously and has undertaken an appropriate course of action to ensure that the opinions of residents are and will be fully considered in the processing of the planning application.”CAPTION: Residents of Waterfoot Park have accused the Council of failing to provide a duty of care in relation to a proposed building development.

title: Air ambulance responds to 140 local calls during second year in service
story: THE air ambulance service which this month is celebrating its second anniversary has responded to  emergency calls in the Newry, Mourne and Down Council area.Overall, the helicopter emergency service has responded to just over  emergency calls Province-wide.The service has a close local link as it was established as a result of a campaign led by the late Dr John Hinds, originally from Portaferry, who combined his two passions for motorbiking and working at the cutting edge of intensive care.From the motorcycling enthusiastrsquos early days in medical school, his focus was on working at the cutting edge of intensive care.He eventually combined these two passions to join the small team of flying doctors at road races who used their motorcycles to get to the scene of an incident within seconds.Dr Hinds was instrumental in leading the campaign for an air ambulance service to be introduced in Northern Ireland and had met with former Stormont Health Minister Simon Hamilton to discuss the issue.Sadly, he lost his le in a crash on the Skerries road racing course in Dublin in July , suffering multiple injuries which proved fatal.However, eight months after Dr Hindsrsquo death, funding was made available for an air ambulance which went into service in July , responding to more than  emergencies in its first year of operation.From its base near Lisburn, the air ambulance can reach any part of Northern Ireland in around  minutes, with its primary role is to deliver advanced care, benefitting those whose lives are at serious risk following signicant injury or trauma, by bringing urgent medical assistance directly to the patient at the scene.Air Ambulance Northern Irelandis the local charity that provides the Helicopter Emergency Medical Service, together with partners at the Northern Ireland Ambulance Service and operates seven days a week for  hours per day.Air ambulance head of fundraising, Kerry Anderson,said each time the helicopter takes off the charity is aware that someone is in great need.ldquoThanks to the generosity of people locally, the emergency medical service can offer the best chance of saving a le, she said.ldquoThe air ambulance is there for everyone and might one day save someonersquos le or that of a loved one. If we all do a little bit, wersquoll ensure the service is maintained for today, tomorrow and future generations.Earlier this year, local politicians agreed to take the lead in securing financial support for the air ambulance service and also make a monetary contribution to help meet the servicersquos poundm annual running costs.The Department of Health allocates around poundm in annual funding to help keep the helicopter service in the air with money used to finance the air ambulance crew, medicines and medical equipment. Charity funds, including public donations, sustains the aviation side of the operation.It was announced recently that as part of the ongoing consultation on reshaping stroke services, the Department has made a commitment to extend the partnership with Air Ambulance Northern Irelandto enable the helicopter emergency medical service to provide a secondary response to incidents, including strokes, by .Health officials have also confirmed that any changes to the existing arrangement would be subject to the completion of an appropriate business case and agreement with the air ambulance with regard to any funding implications..prettyPhoto

title: Charity Beer and Bubbles 5k run in Finnebrogue
story: M B McGRADY  Co Chartered Accountants is setting the pace this September with the launch of the Beer and Bubbles k run in a bid to raise money for Air Ambulance NI.Open to competitors of all ages and experiences, the race will take place on Thursday, September , at Finnebrogue Woods, nestled on the outskirts of Downpatrick.This is the first k race to take place at the idyllic venue, with the route mapped out so runners take in the stunning woodland and finish close to the lakeside, where they will be able to soak up the atmosphere while enjoying a glass of local beer or prosecco.The event follows on from last yearrsquos successful M B Grady  Co Ultimate Aqua Challenge,.Conaill McGrady, director of M B McGrady  Co, said: ldquoWe are delighted to be supporting Air Ambulance NI for a second year and helping to contribute to maintaining the vital work that they do. Last year we held the first Aqua Challenge and this year we wanted to do another first ndash so Bubbles and Beer came to fruition.ldquoJust like last year we are encouraging not only clients, co-workers and friends to take part, but also those within the local community who are looking for a fun challenge.Mr McGrady paid tribute to Ed Lindsay and his team at Finnebrogue Woods, which he described as a stunning location.He added: ldquoWe are working with local event management company,  Extreme, to ensure this is an enjoyable and memorable experience for all involved and encourage people of all abilities to come down and enjoy a walk or run.Air Ambulance NI Area Fundraising Manager, Grace Williams, said: ldquoWe are very proud that M B McGrady  Co are continuing to support Air Ambulance NI with another unique, fun, family event.ldquoItrsquos set to be a great evening and we would love to get as many people as possible taking part, enjoying the evening and raising money for our charity.She added: The Helicopter Emergency Medical Serviceis tasked on average at least once a day. To ensure this is sustained, we need to raise pound million each year so public support is crucial. By taking part yoursquoll be making a lesaving dference and helping to raise vital funds for Air Ambulance NI.Air Ambulance NI works in partnership with the Northern Ireland Ambulance Service to provide the Helicopter Emergency Medical Service for Northern Ireland and is the local accountancy firmrsquos charity partner of choice for the second year.M B McGrady  Co Chartered Accounts has three offices situated in Downpatrick, Belfast and Newtownards.The race starts at .pm, with registration open from .pm. To sign up visit www.mbmcgrady.eventbrite or call   ..prettyPhoto

title: Classy Corey lifts silver at World Youth Savate event
story: AN Annacloy teenager has just ed home from from the Savate World Youth Championships in Budapest with a silver medal.Thirteen year-old Corey McCullough, a member of Joe Ferrisrsquo Bryansford Academy, who was at the championships as part of the Irish team, narrowly missed out on gold to a Russian fighter he had beaten earlier in the competition.Savate, a French combat sport that uses the hands and feet as weapons, combining elements of English boxing with graceful kicking techniques, has been an integral part of Coreyrsquos le for the past three years mdash although he has been kick boxing since he was six.Corey fought in the kg category and he has now set his sights on being part of the Ireland team that will travel to the European Championships next year.A pupil at St Malachyrsquos High School, Castlewellan, Corey is indebted to his coaches Joseph Ferris and Martin OrsquoMalley. He is also extremely grateful to sponsor Philip Polly, from CosyRoof and Brian McElroy, of Premier Chiropractic Centre, Downpatrick..prettyPhoto

title: Downpatrick FC host Golf Day
story: THE clubrsquos annual Golf Day was held last Friday at St Patrickrsquos Golf Club, with over  players playing on a course which was in pristine condition and in glorious sunshine.Unfortunately, nobody was able to take advantage of the playing conditions and get a hole in one at the par three th and secure pound, in cash which was kindly sponsored by Murphyrsquos Bar and Restaurant.The winners were: membersrsquo first prize, Michael Baggley nd Conor McMenamin rd, Mark Fitzsimons. The non-membersrsquo winners were: st Andy Baggley and nd Joe McMahon. The closest to the pin on th was Mark Murphy.The club would like to thank Murphyrsquos Bar  Restaurant for sponsoring the hole-in-one, thank you to Docrsquos Fish  Chip Shops for sponsoring the BBQ and to all our hole sponsors: Niall Powderly and family, Sean McMahon, Connollyrsquos Spar, BMD Contracts, Molloyrsquos Fish  Chip Shop, Bayview Killough Holiday Home, McGreevyrsquos Butchers, Eugene Milligan, MC Dental Laboratory, ALPS, United Mortgages, JRrsquos of Castlewellan, Matts Gardening Service and The : Diet, Down, Lecale  Ards. We would also like to say a special thanks to St Patrickrsquos Golf Club captain Patrick Totton, the members of St Patrickrsquos Golf Club, club professional Charlie Bell and the excellent greenkeepers for allowing us to use their excellent facility.Downpatrick begin their league campaign in Division A tomorrow night with an away fixture against Orangefield OB at Cregagh Sports Club in Belfast. This match kicks off at .pm. Then on Tuesday night they travel to play Rosario YC at Ulidia Playing Fields, this match kicks off at .pm.Over the next few weeks all our teams will be ing to training in preparation for the upcoming season, keep an eye on our Social Media pages for more information..prettyPhoto

title: Fred seals win in added time
story: A FREDDIE OrsquoConnor point in added time gave Bright a stirring victory over second-placed St Paulrsquos at Pairc Mac Con Midhe on Friday night.The game was played in perfect conditions with a slight sea breeze being the only element for players to contend with.Bright took possession from the throw-in and ultimately controlled the early part of the game. They opened the scoring through Gareth George and he added a free to give the visitors an early cushion.Indeed, Bright had plenty more chances to add to this score, but were wasteful in their shot selection. The Holywood men finally woke up and a tidy score from Connor McAnespie after  minutes opened their account.Bright again replied with a fine score from Marc Burke before Martin Cox opened his account for Holywood with a point after  minutes. Barry Kilkey levelled the contest three minutes later from close range and Freddie OrsquoConnor scored for Bright to edge them ahead again.Foolish tackling and unnecessary frees were costing St Paulrsquos in the game and helped Bright dominate the play In the first half.The gamersquos opening goal, however, swung the play towards the Holywood men again. Fantastic work from Seaacuten Tucker around the middle of the park and his long ball into the danger area found Marty Cox in space.Cox caught the ball in mid-air, landed and turned in one motion before smashing the ball past Michael Ferrand, who had no chance. The sizable crowd roared with delight and momentum was now with St Paulrsquos as Tucker added another score from play.Once again, however, ill discipline and poor tackling would cost St Paulrsquos. Paddy Falls high tackle left George with a handy free to cut the deficit before Tucker added a free from m out on the left.George added the final score of the half for Bright leaving St Paulrsquos two points clear at the half-time whistle - to -.Bright again took the early initiative at the start of the second half and a point by Rian Tempany set the early tone. A big talking point came at six minutes into the second half when referee John McMullan sent off two players, one from each team after an altercation at a break downThe next few scores were to and fro with Tucker scoring three points and George replying in kind, aided by Tempany. The game was tied at - to - drawing at  when St Paulrsquosadded their second goal in the th minute.Fine work from Daniel Eastwood and Cox set up Tucker who danced around two Bright defenders before slotting the ball home from  metres. The home crowd were again in raptures, expecting St Paulrsquos to see the game out.However, game management has been a big problem this season for the Holywood men, given the average age of the team is  it is perhaps understandable that experience to see games out is just not there yet.St Paulrsquos tried to slow the game down, but with about  minutes still to be played, it was far too early for that. Bright caught St Paulrsquos in possession on numerous occasionsand turned the ball over for score after score.George was a constant threat and punished each mistake by the Holywood men with a score. Ably assisted by Freddie OrsquoConnor, the pair hauled the St Paulrsquos lead in until it was all square by the th minute.They again caught St Paulrsquos out and OrsquoConnor scored the winning point in the st minute.St Paulrsquos: Craig McKenna, Owen Loughran, Conor McPeake, Ryan Loughran, Ruairi Collins, Paddy Falls, Michael Collins , Gerard Walls, Patrick Eastwood, Martin Cox , Seaacuten Tucker , Daniel Eastwood, Barry Kilkey , Conor McAnespie . Subs: Daacuteire McGrattan. Ryan Hughes, Conleth Rooney, Rodney Adams, Colm OrsquoConnor, Matthew Crozier, Josh Johnston, Fintan Eastwood, Euan Morrow.Bright: Michael Farrand, Niall Byrne, Barry Mageean, Noel Travers, Corey Ranaghan, Nicholas OrsquoConnor, Freddie OrsquoConnor , Cailean Toner, Seamas Tumelty, Jack McLaughlin, Declan Trainor , Gareth George , Marc Burke , Kevin Groves , Owen McEvoy. Subs: Martin Murphy, Oran Tumelty, Christopher Byrne, James Hanna, Joseph Farrand, Rian Tempany , Declan Quinn, Jude McCrissican.St Paulrsquos -Bright -ACFL DIVISION .prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C July 31%2C 1979
story: DOWNPATRICK mdash Downpatrick is believed to have been put under the microscope for possible inclusion in the itinerary for the Popersquos three-day visit to Ireland.The programme for the Popersquos visit has already been drawn up and dispatched to Rome, but no one is willing to confirm that Downpatrick is on the list.The Primate, Cardinal Thomas OrsquoFiaich, was unavailable for comment, but a spokesman for him said that he could not comment on the matter. He did, however, admit that the itinerary has been sent to Rome.Venues for the Popersquos visit are pure speculation and certainly newspapers are free to speculate, he added.It is understood that Downpatrick was one of the three venues north of the border suggested by the committee of  bishops, headed by Cardinal OrsquoFiaich, when they met last week.The decision on whether the Pope will include Northern Ireland in his tour will be taken in Rome, but it is believed that alternative venues in the Republic have been suggestedthe Pope decides not to cross the border.The choice of Downpatrick mdash with its strong historical links with Christianity and St Patrick mdash is understood to have been a move to give the Pope the opportunity to see as many people as possible.It is also thought that Armagh mdash the ecclesiastical headquarters of the Roman Catholic Church in Ireland mdash and Londonderry were studied as possible venues for a visit.Until the programme is finalised, the only places certain to be included in the itinerary are Dublin and the Marian Shrine at Knock, County Mayo.Dr Joseph Maguire, Parish Priest of Downpatrick, said that he personally had not been contacted about any visit from Pope John Paul II, but he admitted that Downpatrick would have been one of the first places to think of.ldquoWe would be delighted to be so honoured with a visit from the Holy Father and he would be most welcome he said.KILLYLEAGH mdash A one-day token strike by production workers closed the Killyleagh Mill yesterday.Around  workers walked out, seeking a wages increase. It is understood that negotiations are going on around the table to try and thrash out a compromise.The token strike, which is also hitting other linen firms in the province, is expected to be prolonged unless the workers receive what they are seeking.TYRELLA mdash An extensive redevelopment of Tyrella Beach has been earmarked in a draft report which proposes to bring most of the beach area into public ownership.The report prepared by a group of consultant engineers working for the Down District Council has been described as ldquohighly practical and has already been given council approval.No cost estimates have yet been carried out on the scheme, but senior council officials are already preparing the way to convince the Department of Commerce and the Northern Ireland Tourist board to supply the necessary money.If the plan goes ahead the biggest change in the appearance of Tyrella will be the absence of cars on the beach area. Two special zones will be developed for car parking on either side of the beach and a park for upwards of  cars will be provided in the centre, off the beach area.Under no circumstances, however, will cars be allowed to drive up and down the beach area and the council is expected to appoint full-time beach inspectors to supervise parking during the summer season.The private entrances presently used by beach-goers will be blocked off and two new public driveways will be constructed. It is thought that charges for cars to the beach will be scrapped.Other developments at the beach will include the provision of new toilet blocks and the construction of - self-catering holiday homes for renting.NEWCASTLE mdash A new peal of six church bells will ring out over Newcastle this year. They will be installed in St Johnrsquos Parish Church, which will be  years old in .Dr Noel Warren, the rector, says the parishioners are looking forward with tremendous interest to hearing the first peal of new bells to be installed in any church in Ireland for many years. The installation scheme will cost pound,, of which pound, has already been raised.The only special event to raise money has been a coffee party by Mr and Mrs Gerald Annesley. It produced about pound,.The church has always been under the patronage of the Annesley family who paid a great deal of its construction cost.STRANGFORD mdash The Roads Division has confirmed the report in the Recorder last week that the Cranglersquos Rock Corner, near Strangford, is to be re-aligned mdash and they have announced a firm starting date.A spokesman admitted this week that work had already started but he explained that this was only preliminary to the actual scheme to re-align the three bends, and was being carried out with the consent of local landowners.The spokesman also admitted that the scheme had been brought forward from its original starting date of - because of pressure from district councillors and local people.ARDGLASS mdash The death took place on Monday of one of the most popular persons in the area, William Curran, of Ardglass. Sailor Bill , as he was known, was born in Blaneystown and was a nephew of that other great Sheepland character, Willrsquos Billy Curran.In , Sailor joined the Royal Navy and his -year hitch took him through the first World War and some time in the West Indies.When he retired from the navy he became restless at home and decided he would give the minefields in Scotland a try.After his first day down in Ayrshire pit he was very disillusioned and decided not tobut he was prevailed upon to give it at least another day. He did and this day turned into  years.CROSSGAR mdash Crossgar man David McClurg continued on his winning ways with his Jersey cows at the County Antrim Agricultural Show at Antrim on Saturday.Having won the championship at Omagh and Castlewellan Shows, he made it a hat-trick of successes.Not only did he win the Granger Cup for the champion Jersey, but also the Lever Cup for the champion heer, the Lawther Cup for the best group and the first winner of the Eagle Cup for the Jersey with the best udder.KILLOUGH mdash A nephew of the late Canon Napier, of Killough, has been conferred the honour of Knighthood of St Gregory by Pope John Paul II. Dr S Napier, who has been in practice in Derby, for the last  years, received the honour recently.TEMPLE mdash Banbridgersquos Noel Hudson became the latest name to enter the Temple  record books when he won two races on Saturday.But it was Dromara Destroyer Ray McCullough, who caught the eye of the locals as he won the cc class to chalk up his th first place over the Temple course since first racing there  years ago.Many doubted McCulloughrsquos ability to win at the temple on Saturday. Since his spectacular fallin the North West last year, he hasnrsquot been registering victories as often mdash but they reckoned without his love for the Temple course and watched eagerly as he ran up another success.GAA mdash Loughinisland for so long known as the lsquogypsiesrsquo of East Down football, as far as playing pitches is concerned, have at last come of age.On Sunday their new ground and permanent home will be officially opened by Paddy McFlynn, the president of the GAA.The Loughinisland club was founded at the start of the present century and in their  years they have, at ious times, played on pitches throughout theand breadth of the parish..prettyPhoto

title: Full steam ahead for dinosaur adventures
story: THE Downpatrick and County Down Railwayrsquos programme of summer events got underway last week to a lsquoroaringrsquo success.The Jurassic Express was the first big event of the railwayrsquos exciting summer programme and was more successful than they could possibly have imagined.Railway chairman Robert Gardiner said: ldquoWho knew dinosaurs and railways went together ldquoWe had baby dinos and their keepers on the train, and when the train got to Inch Abbey the passengers disembarked and walked down to our picnic area where lsquoRoaryrsquo the T-Rex was waiting for them.He added: ldquoEven though you know they are puppets, itrsquos still quite unsettling when Roary the T-Rex charges at you.ldquoWe carried over  dino-fans on five packed-out trains throughout the day, with people travelling as far as Dublin.Visitor Jen Banks said: ldquoIt was fantastic, my son Lorcaacuten was beside himself and daughter Sarola was terried. The train is lovely and all the volunteers made it so special. Fab time.Lee Monahan commented: ldquoAnother great day thanks again guys.Lynsey Smyth said: ldquoWas a great day. My wee boy Olly had a ball.Elaine McMillan said: ldquoWe had a great day. Think I was worse than the kids for enjoying it.Ranger Claire Johnston, from Jurassic Hire, said: ldquoWe had so much fun on the day. We love what we do and enjoy it as much as the kids,not more.ldquoWhilst researching my daughterrsquos dinosaur-themed party, I realised that Northern Ireland was lacking le size T-Rex dinosaurs to hire.ldquoI decided I would take a leap of faith and jump into the crazy world of family entertainment. I havenrsquot looked back. I love what I do. I love seeing the expressions on peoplersquos faces when they see a full size dinosaur.Mr Gardiner said the programme of special events, supported by Newry Mourne  Down Council, continues throughout the summer months.ldquoOur next one is the lsquoSuperTrainrsquo on August  where the Avengers battle the evil Red Skull to stop the demise of the Downpatrick  County Down Railway from happening as he plans to turn all the steam trains into dirty diesels.This August also sees the start of some events for the grown-ups at the DCDR, with the first of these events giving wine-lovers a chance to enjoy some Hungarian wines with the lsquoWhistle and Winersquo steam trains this Saturday and the lsquoGin Expressrsquo on August .A full list of events can be found online at www.downrail..prettyPhoto

title: Kodi (11) to be laid to rest
story: BRAVE little Kodi Brown from Killinchy will be buried tomorrow after a year-long fight against a brain tumour.The  year-old died last Tuesday in the arms of her mother and surrounded by her family after receiving pioneering medical treatment in Germany.More than pound, was raised by local supporters and well-wishers to fund the specialised treatment which was not available in the UK.Her funeral service will be held in St Maryrsquos Parish Church, Kilmood, and will be followed by interment in the adjoining graveyard.Kodirsquos mother, Gemma, announced the tragic news on Kodirsquos Krew fundraising Facebook page last week, saying: ldquoThe most beautul soul is now free from the most brutal disease.Mrs Brown said she was ldquoblessed and honoured to have been her mum and that her ldquoprecious little girl was not only my daughter but one of the best friends I have ever had.ldquoThe light, the joy and the motivation she brought into my le and to so many others will leave an agonising void, continued Mrs Brown.ldquoShe made me proud in abundance. Her ability to converse with people of all ages was remarkable. Quick-witted and vivacious, she could captivate her audiences with compelling stories of her own experiences and those from her dazzling imagination.ldquoHer mothering compassionate nature led her to help those troubled or in need and she was often courageous in doing so, especially with being so sensitive herself.Mrs Brown added that her family and the local community had lost ldquoa little hero and spoke of her daughterrsquos ability to love.ldquoIf Kodi loved you, you knew. She expressed her love openly to her family and friends daily, which is a quality I deeply admired and in her last weeks she used all her strength to tell us.Mrs Brown, who was with Kodi constantly during her treatment in Germany, spoke of her pain at losing her eldest child and only daughter.ldquoThe overwhelming pain I feel from losing the greatest gt of a daughter and to no longer be able to help her achieve her dreams, aspirations and all the special milestones I expected to experience with her will haunt me each day until I am called to be her mummy again.ldquoFor now, my darling son and I must find a way to live on through the pain. The power of love mdash we are forever broken.Kodi took ill last February during her P year at Killinchy Primary School while playing at a friendrsquos house. Initially diagnosed with a viral infection, she continued to take seizures at home.In May after a routine MRI, her family were told that there was still swelling on her brain. Four weeks later, the worst news that Kodi had a brain tumour was confirmed and there were no curative treatments available.Her family refused to give up hope and took Kodi to Germany on a self-funded trip where pioneering immunotherapy was offered, alongside infusion treatments.However, the costs of the treatment were prohibitive and Gemmarsquos friends created the Kodirsquos Krew fundraising appeal to fund the treatment and living costs.The Killinchy community and her school backed the fundraising effort with local events being held weekly.Killinchy Primary School principal Chris Currie last night spoke of losing Kodi ldquowho was loved by everyone.ldquoThe whole school community is devastated at Kodirsquos loss, he said. ldquoShe was very much a bright light. She was just so brave. The strength and maturity it took to go through what she did as such a young child was so impressive to us all.ldquoKodi will be massively missed and we will remember and celebrate her positivity as she was always up for a laugh and a bit of banter.Mr Currie said that the school threw itself as a community into the fundraising effort as well as supporting the family, particularly her brother Blake who also attends the school.ldquoWhen something like this happens to a child whorsquos one of our own, we give everything to do and have done our best to stand with the family and support them, he added.ldquoOur job now is to help the family deal with the aftermath and we will support the parents and Blake with whatever support we can give.Mr Currie said that he was overwhelmed by Kodirsquos maturity when she addressed a special school assembly in May and paid her thanks to the pupilsrsquo parents for helping her family with the treatment costs.Kodi is survived by her mother, Gemma, dad Andy, brother Blake, grandparents and extended family circle..prettyPhoto

title: Make a Wish is the winner
story: THE th Kevin Gorman Memorial Cup drew a massive crowd to Meadowvale, Drumaness, on Saturday.The annual fundraiser for the Make a Wish Foundation is run by Jackie and Shane Gorman mdash Kevinrsquos mother and brother mdash in memory of Kevin who tragically lost his le attempting to save a PSNI colleague in .Sixteen youth teams played in a tournament, before the main match which saw Drumaness Mills beating the PSNI - for the honour of the memorial cup in its last year.There was a number of attractions for the children throughout the family fun day, and the day concluded with music throughout the evening in the clubhouse.Jackie and Shane would like to thank everyone for their support throughout the years, including their loyal volunteers, sponsors, and Drumaness Mills for the use of their facilities.ldquoIt would be impossible to thank every inidual, but you know who you are and we extend our warmest and heartfelt thanks, Jackie said.ldquoIt was indeed fitting that the Mills won the cup in its final year, and this saw Kevinrsquos two daughters, Shannyn and Abi, present the cup to his brother, Shane..prettyPhoto

title: Pedestrian crossing required to address Newcastle safety issue
story: ROADS officials have been asked to consider providing a pedestrian crossing at Newcastlersquos South Promenade.The suggestion mdash to help improve driver and pedestrian safety at this busy part of the resort mdash was made recently by South Down MLA Colin McGrath during a meeting with Department for Infrastructure and Newry, Mourne and Down Council officials.The MLA said people who have to enter South Promenade have to contend with a busy traffic flow, with vehicles making their way to and from the Kilkeel direction.Mr McGrath continued: ldquoThis is a busy thoroughfare at all times of the day. As you leave the centre of Newcastle this particular road narrows and there are also a number of parked cars.ldquoUnfortunately, this high level of traffic has given rise to a number of speeding issues and there have been a number of collisions. Several years ago, a local man also lost his le in an accident at this part of the town.Mr McGrath explained that residents were keen to see a new crossing provided, suggesting that an ideal location would be at the bottom of Bath Lane.He explained: ldquoThis would allow pedestrians to cross the road in a safe manner but also form another connection between King Street and the Kilkeel Road. I have also contacted the local council to request the installation of a second pedestrian railing going down the steps at Bath Lane as a health and safety measure.Mr McGrath said it was important that roads and footpaths in the resort were safe, issuing an appeal to road users lower their speed and be mindful of their fellow road users..prettyPhoto

title: Saintfield director scoops accolades for 2:40 to London
story: HErsquoS done it again. A Saintfield writer and director has received more plaudits at a major British film festival.Gavin Irvine scooped Best Film and Best Comedy awards at the Brighton Rocks Film Festival for his hit comedy film, : to London.Gavin beat off stf competition with other entries in the comedy category alone.He said afterwards: ldquoI was shell-shocked when I heard my name being called out. I just canrsquot believe the run of good fortune Irsquom receiving.ldquoComedy is the hardest genre to be successful in. Probably becausecomedy is so subjective. You either get it or you donrsquot.The movie : to London has been described as a ldquoa wry Beckettian homage to the great British spy thriller but with carrots and beards.ldquoI suppose because the film is totally original, while it takes its influences from British Ealing comedy and the classic comedy era, it goes further with the idea of espionage and the spy thrillers mixed with some extremely dry wit, he remarked.ldquoThe comedy has been doing the short film festival circuit in London this year and the feedback has been amazing.ldquoMost notably, critics say the film is very original. For me, as a film-maker, lsquoploughing your own furrowrsquo is what itrsquos all about.ldquoI donrsquot want to be an imitator. I want to lead but, of course, this is extremely hard to do.Gavin is no stranger to the industryrsquos red carpet events with : to London having won the Audience Award at the Making Waves Film Festival in Portsmouth in  and Best Short Film at the German International Film Festival and the Brazil International Film Festival. It also received the Special Jury Award at the Canadian Independent Film Festival.Gavin, who fell into filming making over  years ago and was winning awards within two years. Earlier this year he scooped Best Short Screenplay for his latest film, Lunch, and the Rising Star Award for his debut music video, Rattling My Chains, at the Portuguese International Festival..prettyPhoto

title: Tributes paid to popular GP after motor racing accident
story: TRIBUTES have been paid to a Belfast GP who died in a crash at Kirkistown motor racing circuit on Saturday.Father-of-three, Dr Paul Conn , was a partner at a Belfast practice and had celebrated a win earlier in the day.An Air Ambulance was called to the scene following the accident but Dr Connrsquos le could not be saved. The rest of the meeting was abandoned.Observers say it was a ldquoracing accident which happened as Dr Conn attempted to overtake a slower car on the home straight.His sports car clipped the other car and was sent crashing off the track. Despite rapid response teams being available, Dr Conn was pronounced dead at the scene.Dr Conn had been a member of  Motor Racing Club Of Ireland for over  years and was described by them as a top racer who will be sorely missed.A spokesman for the club said: ldquoPaul was from Lisburn. He joined our club in  and during the intervening years he campaigned his lsquoCrossleacute Srsquo sports car with increasing success.ldquoIn  he seemed to reach a new level of skill and began to trouble the established top echelon of drivers in road sports, winning in the second race of the May meeting.Referring to Dr Connrsquos success on Saturday, he said: ldquoHe had already won the first road sports race, against top opposition, and he was on course for a repeat in the second race when he had an accident opposite the control tower.ldquoBecause of the location of the incident, our doctors and the Order Of Malta personnel were in attendance almost immediately, but unfortunately Paul succumbed to his injuries at the scene.ldquoOnce again, we offer our sincere condolences to Paulrsquos family, friends, colleagues and team. He will be sorely missed.Meanwhile in a statement, Motorsport UK said it was investigating the circumstances.A spokesman said: ldquoAs with all serious incidents in or around UK motor sport, Motorsport UK is now working with the event-organising club and the police to establish precisely what happened on this occasion.He added: ldquoMotorsport UK sends its sincere condolences to the family and friends of the deceased driver.A PSNI spokesman said it was ldquoinvestigating the circumstances surrounding the death of a man at a race track in Kircubbin on Saturday afternoon. A report will be prepared for the coroner.Jim Shannon MP for Strangford expressed his sympathy to Dr Connrsquos family.He said: ldquoThe tragedy that took the le of Dr Conn shocked all of those at the Belfast and District Motorsport Club and the wider sporting community.ldquoThe circuit at Kirkistown is a popular location for car, kart and motornike enthusiasts and it has in the past had three other fatalities, but this is the first one in a car.ldquoDr Conn had been a GP for almost all of this working le and this terrible accident has taken a family man and a wonderful GP from a community that is grieving his loss.He added: ldquoTo his family circle at this time, I know I speak for all in this community when I extend our heartfelt and sincere condolences and prayers at this time..prettyPhoto

title: Ursula’s special day at Spa
story: SPA lady president Ursula Kelly hosted the clubrsquos third major event of the season on Friday with her Lady Presidentrsquos Day competition mdash played in glorious sunshine on a course which continues to attract so much favourable comment.Once again it was Carol Shields who topped the leaderboard, continuing her outstanding season long success with a fantastic score of  points.Pam Trohear was also on top form, taking the gross prize while Gwyneth Cordner was second and Elaine Beattie was third.Philip Shields was the leading man in the nine-hole menrsquos competition after facing fierce competition from Pat Savage, who was second, and Graham Mills, who finished third.The lady president said that for her it had been ldquoa very special day and after congratulating all the winners, thanked everyone involved in the preparation and presentation of the event and all who had competed.She paid tribute to the ldquohard work and efficiency of handicap secretary Gillian Earls, ladysecretary Catherine McEvoy, lady captain LizGeddes and the ladiesrsquo committee along with Marian Armstrong and Heather Edgar in the office, juvenile convenor Gwyneth Cordner, professional Gary Wardlow, the bar, catering and grounds staff.ldquoI want to thank my family and extended family for the support they have given me over the past two years and especially my long suffering husband Jimmy. I donrsquot think I could have done it without them, the lady president said.Tom Coburn, Sparsquos president, congratulated Ursula on what he called a ldquofantastic day for the club and said the evening turnout for the prize giving spoke for itself of the high esteem in which she was held by all the members.ldquoFor all the time and effort you have put in to this day well done Ursula mdash it was a great success, he said.Results: st Carol Shields, nd Gwyneth Cordner rd Elaine Beattie gross,gross, Pam Trohear committee prize, Liz Geddes past captains, Sally Ann Douglas juvenile, Ellie Smith visitors, Mary McGrath nine hole competition, Bronagh Hunt nearest the pin at nd, Catherine McEvoy nearest the line at th, Maureen West.Menrsquos: st Philip Shields, nd Pat Savage, rd Graham Mills..prettyPhoto

title: fermanagh peer calls mlas get back work
story: A Fermanagh peer has said people are ldquofed up to the teeth at the ongoing impasse at Stormont and called on MLAs here to get back to work.Viscount Brookeborough, The Queenrsquos Lord Lieutenant for County Fermanagh, told the House of Lords last week that ldquo per cent of people in Northern Ireland want a restoration of our devolved Parliament.ldquo per cent of the normal people in Northern Ireland are totally and absolutely frustrated by our political parties not getting together. We should forget who is to blame.ldquoThe people around us at home are fed up to the teeth with the politicians whom they elected to our Assembly being, for whatever reason, incapable of sorting something out for us, he said.Directing his remarks at his fellow peers, Viscount Brookeborough said: ldquoAlthough you are no longer Assembly Members, go back home and get your parties to agree.ldquoGet there, talk and produce a legitimate Government for us in Northern Ireland.
